record.question: Mr. Blackwood, can you describe the manuscript you were asked to appraise in detail – its age, condition, and any unique markings it possessed?
record.feedback: The manuscript appeared to be a 15th-century illuminated text, showing some age-related wear but was remarkably well-preserved, and it featured a unique crest depicting a raven clutching a Hawthorne bloom in its beak.

record.question: Ms. Carter, you mentioned disagreeing with Dr. Hawthorne’s interpretation of his discovery. Can you be more specific about *what* aspects of his work you disputed?
record.feedback: He relied heavily on anecdotal evidence, which I believe compromised the validity of his conclusions and frankly, undermined the established historical consensus.

record.question: Ms. Whitfield, you mentioned needing a scarf. Where did you purchase this scarf, and can anyone corroborate your presence there around the time of the murder?
record.feedback: A scarf? Oh dear, it was at… Miller's Haberdashery, a lovely little shop, and the owner, Mr. Abernathy, he always has such interesting ties, and I think I was there around lunchtime, but I couldn’t possibly be certain, everything is just a blur right now.

record.question: Mr. Hawthorne, can you describe your relationship with Reginald Thorne and how often you interacted with him in the weeks leading up to his death?
record.feedback: Reginald was my uncle, and while we weren’t particularly close, I interacted with him a few times a week regarding family estate matters and recent potential changes to his will.

record.question: Ms. Wellington, were you aware of the extent of Reginald Thorne’s art collection, and had you ever discussed it with him, perhaps regarding potential redesigns or appraisals?
record.feedback: Oh dear, art collections... my aunt Mildred collected porcelain dolls, you wouldn't *believe* the dust, and no, I mostly just focused on the library, it was such a lovely room with all those books, and I really didn't pay much attention to anything else.

record.question: Dr. Blackwood, did you have any professional dealings with Reginald Thorne regarding the authentication or valuation of any paintings in his collection?
record.feedback: Yes, I was engaged to assess a newly acquired painting for Mr. Thorne, which is why I was at the manor that day.

record.question: Mr. Kingsley, were you familiar with Reginald Thorne’s views on modern art, and did you ever discuss your work with him?
record.feedback: Yes, I was aware he appreciated classic styles and we briefly discussed my work, though he didn't offer specific critique.

record.question: Ms. Pritchard, you mentioned being engrossed in a book during the time of the murder. Could you recall the title of that book and perhaps a specific detail about what you were reading?
record.feedback: Oh, it was a rather dark tale, a mystery actually, about a poisoning with…nightshade, I believe.

record.question: Mr. Hawthorne, you mentioned potential changes to your uncle's will. Could you elaborate on the nature of those changes and your potential benefit from them?
record.feedback: I understood there was discussion of altering the will, and naturally, as a family member, I would have benefited from maintaining my expected inheritance, but I wasn’t privy to the specifics of any proposed changes.

record.question: Dr. Blackwood, can you describe the painting you were assessing for Mr. Thorne? Was it a recent acquisition, and did Mr. Thorne express any particular enthusiasm – or skepticism – about it?
record.feedback: It was a stunning landscape piece, recently acquired, and Mr. Thorne seemed quite proud of it, though I detected a subtle nervousness about its provenance.

record.question: Mr. Kingsley, did you happen to notice anyone behaving suspiciously during your time at the manor?
record.feedback: I did observe Eleanor Blackwood leaving the library looking quite flustered and in a hurry earlier in the evening.

record.question: Ms. Pritchard, you mentioned reading a mystery novel about poisoning. Did that book happen to be a recent read, or something you've read before? And if recent, where did you acquire it?
record.feedback: It was a new one, I picked it up at Old Man Hemlock’s apothecary just yesterday – he has a surprising selection of books alongside his remedies.

record.question: Professor Bennett, can you describe your professional relationship with Dr. Harper, and were there any recent disagreements or tensions between you two?
record.feedback: We had a long-standing professional rivalry, and while generally cordial, there was underlying tension due to her recent successes eclipsing my own research.

record.question: Ms. Collins, can you tell me about the last time you saw Dr. Harper, and what was discussed during that meeting?
record.feedback: I last saw Dr. Harper in the library around 7:30 PM, where we were discussing the potential exhibition and unfortunately had a disagreement regarding how our work would be presented together.

record.question: Mr. Sinclair, you were at the mansion discussing funding. Can you detail the nature of that discussion and, specifically, Dr. Harper’s reaction to your proposals?
record.feedback:
‌
I was outlining a potential investment opportunity involving rare botanical specimens, and Dr. Harper seemed… surprisingly dismissive, almost agitated, about the potential risks involved.

record.question: Mr. Whitaker, are you familiar with the antique brass candlestick that was used as the murder weapon? If so, can you describe it and tell me if you've ever seen it at the mansion before?
record.feedback: Oh, candlesticks...yes, terribly shiny they were, quite a polish, you know my grandmother used to polish silver, it was a whole process with special cloths, and... well, yes, I saw one in the library, a lovely piece, very ornate, though I've seen similar ones at auctions, honestly, all over!

record.question: Ms. Thompson, as a journalist who has covered Dr. Harper extensively, were you aware of any enemies she may have had, or anyone who stood to benefit from her…silencing?
record.feedback: During my interviews and observations, I didn’t detect any overt animosity towards Dr. Harper, but I did notice a certain professional jealousy from a rival historian, Professor Alistair Finch.

record.question: Professor Bennett, Ms. Thompson mentioned a rival historian, Alistair Finch. Can you comment on your relationship with him and whether you've discussed Dr. Harper with him recently?
record.feedback: I know Alistair Finch by reputation, but our interactions are limited, and I haven’t discussed Dr. Harper with him in quite some time.

record.question: Ms. Collins, you mentioned a disagreement with Dr. Harper about the exhibition. Could you be more specific about what that disagreement entailed and what was at stake for you personally?
record.feedback: The disagreement centered on the prominence of her recent discoveries versus my curated exhibition, and my concern was that her findings might overshadow years of my dedicated work.

record.question: Mr. Sinclair, you mentioned Dr. Harper was agitated about the risks involved with the botanical specimens. Can you elaborate on those risks and why they might have upset her?
record.feedback: Well, I suggested acquiring some rather potent, and potentially dangerous, plants, and Dr. Harper alluded to a previous incident involving a similar specimen and a… regrettable outcome, though she didn’t specify what that was.

record.question: Mr. Whitaker, given your expertise in antiques, would you say the candlestick used in the murder appeared to be regularly used and maintained, or more of a display piece that hadn’t been handled in some time?
record.feedback: Oh dear, handled...well, I collect stamps too, you know, rare ones, and they *must* be handled with gloves, but the candlestick...it was...dusty, I think, or maybe it was just the light, it’s so hard to tell with antiques, isn’t it?

record.question: Can you describe your typical daily routine when working for Mr. Hargrove?
record.feedback: Well, I usually arrived at 9 AM, managed his schedule, and dealt with correspondence, though lately he seemed…distracted, and things were rather chaotic.

record.question: Were you aware of any recent business dealings of Jonathan Hargrove that might have created conflict with others?
record.feedback: Jonathan mentioned acquiring a particularly valuable piece from a somewhat unscrupulous dealer, and I believe he was anticipating some pushback regarding its authenticity.

record.question: Did you have any professional disagreements with Jonathan Hargrove regarding recent real estate projects?
record.feedback: Yes, Jonathan recently removed me from a significant development deal, causing me substantial professional and financial concern.

record.question: Were you familiar with the antique collection at Hargrove’s mansion, and specifically, the marble statue used in the crime?
record.feedback: Oh, goodness, marble statues... they remind me of my grandmother's garden gnomes, she collected those, you wouldn't *believe* how many, and yes, I did notice the statue, it was very…white, I think, and shiny, and I was just trying to get the lighting right, really!

record.question: Did Jonathan Hargrove ever confide in you about any threats he may have received, or any fears for his safety?
record.feedback: No, Jonathan never mentioned any threats or fears for his safety to me during our discussions.

record.question: Besides the chaos you mentioned, did you notice anything *specific* about Mr. Hargrove's behavior in the days leading up to his death – any particular visitors, phone calls, or meetings that seemed unusual?
record.feedback: Now that you mention it, he did receive a rather heated phone call a few days ago, and seemed quite agitated afterward, muttering something about a "debt" – could that be relevant?

record.question: Can you elaborate on the development deal Jonathan Hargrove removed you from? What were the financial stakes involved?
record.feedback: It was the Riverbend Heights project, and being excluded meant a potential loss of several million dollars in projected revenue for my firm and a significant blow to my professional standing.

record.question: Could you provide more details about the “unscrupulous dealer” Jonathan Hargrove was dealing with, and the “valuable piece” in question?
record.feedback: I only overheard Jonathan mentioning a name – Victor Martel – and something about a recently discovered Renaissance painting, but I wasn’t privy to specifics of their arrangement.

record.question: You mentioned adjusting the lighting. Where exactly were you positioned in relation to the marble statue when you were doing this?
record.feedback: Oh, positioning… well, I was… um, I think I had a ladder, yes, a rather wobbly one actually, and I was near the… the drapes, I think they were velvet, a very dark shade of blue, and the statue was just… there, you know, in the middle, and I kept dropping screws! It was awful.

record.question: Can you describe your relationship with Jonathan Blake before his exposé on you?
record.feedback: Jonathan and I had a purely professional relationship, though it became strained as he began digging into my past work.

record.question: What exactly were you doing at the abandoned warehouse last night, and can you be specific about the times?
record.feedback: Honestly, I was just taking a shortcut through the area and happened to walk past the warehouse around 10 PM, but didn't go inside or stay long.

record.question: Do you routinely patrol near the abandoned warehouse, and if so, did you notice anything unusual last night?
record.feedback: Oh, goodness, the warehouse…yes, I do, I really do, but my cat, Mittens, she *loves* tuna, you wouldn’t believe how much she loves it, and last night? Well, everything seemed…normal, as normal as an abandoned warehouse can be, I suppose, although I did hear a noise earlier in the day.

record.question: You and Jonathan Blake had a falling out. Can you describe the nature of that disagreement and when it occurred?
record.feedback: Our disagreement stemmed from a professional dispute over research materials for our respective books, which happened several months ago and was quite unpleasant, but ultimately resolved.

record.question: Were you aware of any threats made against Jonathan Blake, and if so, can you detail them?
record.feedback: I was aware of David Lawson confronting Jonathan with intense fury at the warehouse around 6:45 PM, which felt like a direct threat.

record.question: Emily Turner claims she witnessed you confronting Jonathan Blake at the warehouse around 6:45 PM. Can you confirm or deny this, and provide your account of the encounter?
record.feedback: Emily must be mistaken, as I left the warehouse well before 6:45 PM, feeling utterly defeated after our discussion.

record.question: You stated you saw David Lawson confront Jonathan Blake. Can you describe the nature of their argument, and specifically, what did you *hear* them say?
record.feedback: Their argument was loud and heated, and I distinctly heard David accusing Jonathan of stealing information and sabotaging his career.

record.question: You said you walked past the warehouse around 10 PM. Did you see anyone else near the warehouse at that time, or notice anything out of place?
record.feedback: Now that you mention it, I *think* I saw a dark-colored car speeding away as I walked by, which seemed odd for that location.

record.question: You mentioned hearing a noise earlier in the day. Can you describe that noise, and approximately what time did you hear it?
record.feedback: A noise… oh dear, noises are the worst, they really are, my Aunt Carol once thought she heard a ghost, but it was just the pipes! It was sort of a…a clanging, like metal on metal, I think, and it was around 3:00 PM, maybe? Or was it closer to lunchtime? I had a ham sandwich, you see…

record.question: : Can you describe your relationship with Dr. Hartwell, and were there any recent disagreements between the two of you?
record.feedback: : Dr. Hartwell was my mentor and a significant figure in my academic life, and while we had a rather intense discussion about my research just before the tragedy, it was simply a passionate exchange of ideas, not a disagreement.

record.question: : What specifically were you tasked with doing at the manor regarding Dr. Hartwell’s collection, and did you notice anything unusual while working?
record.feedback:
‌
I was hired to catalog Dr. Hartwell’s extensive butterfly collection, and honestly, the sheer number of specimens was unusual in itself – it felt…obsessive, almost.

record.question: : You and Dr. Hartwell were known rivals. Can you elaborate on the nature of your rivalry, and when was the last time you spoke with her?
record.feedback: Our rivalry was purely academic, stemming from differing interpretations of historical findings, and I last spoke with her briefly at a conference six months prior.

record.question: : Were you familiar with Dr. Hartwell’s work, and if so, did you ever express interest in acquiring any items from her collection?
record.feedback: Yes, I was familiar with Dr. Hartwell’s work and even discussed potentially donating to her research projects earlier that evening.

record.question: : As Dr. Hartwell’s literary agent, were you aware of any potential conflicts or enemies she may have had, either professionally or personally?
record.feedback: Oh, enemies? Goodness, I… I really prefer hydrangeas to roses, you know, they're just so much more resilient, and I was terribly worried about the seating arrangements for dinner, honestly, but conflicts… well, Professor Blackwood was always rather… intense.

record.question: : You mentioned a "passionate exchange of ideas" with Dr. Hartwell. Can you be more specific about the topic of this discussion and what made it so intense?
record.feedback: : : I was seeking her guidance on my research, and the intensity stemmed from my anxieties about how her new book might impact the visibility of my own work, which she addressed with candid, yet constructive, criticism.

record.question: : You mentioned Dr. Hartwell’s butterfly collection felt “obsessive.” Can you elaborate on what specifically made you feel that way? Were there any peculiarities about the collection’s arrangement or the butterflies themselves?
record.feedback:
‌
‌
It wasn’t anything concrete, just the way they were pinned and displayed – meticulously categorized, with certain rare species almost…guarded, as if he feared someone would take them, which seems a strange concern for butterflies, doesn’t it?

record.question: : Margaret Sinclair mentioned you were “intense.” Was this intensity directed specifically towards Dr. Hartwell, and if so, can you provide an example of a time when your interactions were particularly strained?
record.feedback: I believe Margaret simply recognizes my passionate nature regarding my research, and while Dr. Hartwell and I had disagreements, my intensity was focused on the scholarly debate, not personal animosity.

record.question: : You mentioned discussing a potential donation to Dr. Hartwell’s research. What was the amount you were considering, and what did Dr. Hartwell say about it?
record.feedback: I hadn’t settled on a specific amount, but I mentioned a substantial contribution, and Dr. Hartwell expressed sincere gratitude and excitement about the possibilities.

record.question: Can you describe your activities in the library this evening, specifically between 7pm and 9pm?
record.feedback: I was browsing the history section, quite lost in thought actually, and honestly didn't notice much around me.

record.question: What was the nature of your disagreements with Dr. Montgomery regarding her research?
record.feedback: Dr. Montgomery’s recent publication directly challenged my long-held theories, presenting a rather novel, and frankly, unsubstantiated interpretation of ancient societal structures.

record.question: Were you aware of any tension or conflicts between Dr. Montgomery and any of the other library patrons or academics?
record.feedback: Oh dear, tension... well, my cat, Bartholomew, he *loves* string, you wouldn't believe the lengths he goes to for it, and... oh, the tension! Yes, I suppose Dr. Montgomery and Professor Blackwood sometimes had... differing opinions on historical interpretations, but everyone has opinions, don't they? It was nothing *serious*, I think.

record.question: Did Dr. Montgomery ever express any concerns to you about feeling threatened or unsafe?
record.feedback: Dr. Montgomery mentioned the controversies surrounding her latest book, but she didn't specifically express fear for her safety.

record.question: Can you describe the last time you collaborated with Dr. Montgomery, and what the nature of that collaboration was?
record.feedback: Our last collaboration before today was several months ago when she consulted me on the provenance of a newly acquired medieval manuscript for the library, and I happily provided my expertise.

record.question: You said you were "lost in thought" in the history section. Can you recall *anything* specific you were reading or researching at that time?
record.feedback: Now that you mention it, I seem to recall skimming something about… methods of discreetly disposing of evidence, which is odd, isn't it?

record.question: Did you visit the secluded reading room where Dr. Montgomery was found on the evening of the murder?
record.feedback: I was in the main reading room for a significant portion of the afternoon, and occasionally paced nearby, but I didn’t specifically seek out or enter the secluded room.

record.question: Do you have a record of who checked out the sphinx bookend that was used as the murder weapon? And when was it last checked out?
record.feedback: A bookend? Oh, my goodness, bookends are so important for keeping things tidy, I always tell the assistants... the record... the record! It's... it's somewhere in the system, I just... I haven't looked at it since Tuesday, and Tuesdays are always so busy with the children's story hour, you see, little Timmy spilled juice *everywhere*! I... I don't recall the last checkout, truly.

record.question: Were you aware of Professor Blackwood’s strong disagreement with Dr. Montgomery’s work, and did you ever observe any heated exchanges between them?
record.feedback:
: 

I was aware of their differing opinions, and I saw Professor Blackwood pacing agitatedly near the reading room, but I didn’t witness any direct argument between them.

record.question: Can you describe your working relationship with Dr. Thornton, and were there any recent disagreements or tensions between you two?
record.feedback: Dr. Thornton was my mentor, and while I deeply respected her, I was increasingly anxious about her groundbreaking research potentially diminishing the significance of my own thesis.

record.question: What specific maintenance checks were you performing in the Old Manor library on the evening of Dr. Thornton's death, and can you detail your movements within the library during that time?
record.feedback: I was simply adjusting the thermostat and checking for drafts, moving between the bookshelves and the window to gauge temperature fluctuations.

record.question: Were you aware of the nature of Dr. Thornton’s “groundbreaking research,” and if so, did you have any concerns about how it might impact your own work or reputation?
record.feedback: Yes, I was aware of her research and admittedly felt some professional jealousy as it threatened to overshadow my own life’s work.

record.question: Can you describe the last time you spoke with Dr. Thornton, and what was the conversation about? Be specific.
record.feedback: Oh dear, the last time… well, I do love lilies, you know, they remind me of my grandmother’s garden, and we were discussing the exhibition, specifically the artifact and how important it was, and Eliza was explaining her research, which was… quite unsettling, really.

record.question: Did Dr. Thornton ever express any fears for her safety, or mention anyone who might wish her harm, to you?
record.feedback: Not at all, Dr. Thornton always seemed cheerful and never mentioned feeling unsafe or any potential enemies to me.

record.question: You mentioned anxiety about Dr. Thornton’s research overshadowing your thesis. Can you elaborate on the specific nature of that research and how it related to your own work?
record.feedback: Her research challenged some of the foundational assumptions of my thesis, suggesting my conclusions might be invalid or less impactful.

record.question: Can you describe the “groundbreaking research” Dr. Thornton was conducting in more detail, and what specifically made it a threat to your own work?
record.feedback: Her research centered on a newly discovered interpretation of ancient Mesopotamian texts, which challenged established understandings—understandings my own publications heavily relied upon.

record.question: You mentioned Dr. Thornton's research was "unsettling." Could you elaborate on *why* it was unsettling, beyond simply disagreeing with it?
record.feedback: Unsettling...oh, it was the way she talked about the artifact's origins, and my cat, Mittens, she has the most peculiar habit of batting at dust bunnies, and Eliza suggested it wasn’t what we all thought, that it had a…a darker history, and it made me worry about the exhibition’s reputation, you see.

record.question: Besides adjusting the thermostat and checking for drafts, did you notice anything unusual or anyone else entering or leaving the library that evening?
record.feedback: Now that you mention it, I did briefly see a shadow pass the doorway, but I assumed it was just a member of the household going about their business – was Dr. Thornton expecting visitors that evening?

record.question: Can you describe in detail your conversation with Dr. Hargrave on the evening of the murder?
record.feedback: I briefly spoke with Dr. Hargrave at the party, mostly discussing the dreadful weather, and I can't recall anything particularly noteworthy about the conversation.

record.question: Mr. Langston, were you aware of the controversial nature of Dr. Hargrave's latest research, and if so, what was your opinion of it?
record.feedback: : I was vaguely aware of some debate surrounding his research, but my primary interest was the potential for my manuscript to contribute positively to his work, regardless of the controversy.

record.question: Ms. Bennett, did you examine any of the artifacts in Dr. Hargrave’s library during your visit, and if so, specifically did you handle the marble bust of Julius Caesar?
record.feedback: Oh, dear, the library was so full of things, and it reminded me of my grandmother’s collection of thimbles, and yes, I...I may have just *looked* at the bust, but I wouldn’t touch anything valuable, honestly, I get so clumsy!

record.question: Professor Winters, can you describe the nature of your professional disagreements with Dr. Hargrave, and when was the last time you directly communicated with him?
record.feedback: Our disagreements centered around his increasingly radical interpretations of historical data, and I last spoke with him directly in the library earlier today.

record.question: Mr. Caldwell, what was the potential financial benefit to you if Dr. Hargrave’s book was published, and were you aware of any threats he had received regarding his work?
record.feedback: A successful book launch would have significantly boosted my commission and reputation within the publishing house, and I wasn't privy to any specific threats against Dr. Hargrave, though I did sense he was anxious about the controversial nature of the content.

record.question: Mr. Trent, you mentioned a brief conversation with Dr. Hargrave. Did you notice anyone else interacting with him, or behaving suspiciously, during your time in the library?
record.feedback: "Now that you mention it, I did see Miss Eleanor pacing near the bookshelves while Dr. Hargrave was pouring himself a drink – she seemed quite agitated, almost as if she were waiting for someone, or perhaps concealing something."

record.question: Professor Winters, Mr. Trent mentioned seeing you pacing near the bookshelves while Dr. Hargrave was getting a drink. Can you explain what you were doing at that moment and why you appeared agitated?
record.feedback: I was simply reviewing my notes and formulating counterarguments to Dr. Hargrave’s theories, and my agitation stemmed from the intensity of our intellectual debate.

record.question: Ms. Bennett, you mentioned being clumsy. Can you describe, in detail, exactly *how* you looked at the bust of Julius Caesar? Did you touch it at all, even to steady yourself?
record.feedback: Oh, goodness, detail is so hard! Well, I just… I was admiring it, truly, and there was a little rug, you see, a Persian rug with such faded colors, and I might have… leaned a little closer, just to see the details of his nose, and perhaps my hand grazed it, but it was more of a brush, I think, a very, very light brush, like a butterfly landing, and it reminded me I really must clean my spectacles!

record.question: Mr. Langston, you mentioned a manuscript you hoped to contribute to Dr. Hargrave’s work. What was the nature of this manuscript, and did it in any way challenge or contradict Dr. Hargrave’s existing theories?
record.feedback: : The manuscript is a collection of previously unknown letters detailing the provenance of a historically significant artifact, and while it didn’t directly contradict his theories, it offered a new perspective on its origins.

record.question: Can you describe your relationship with Dr. Graves, and how often you interacted with her?
record.feedback: >I had a purely professional relationship with Dr. Graves, as I was hoping to curate an exhibition of her remarkable art collection, and we’d only met that day to discuss the possibilities.

record.question: Were you aware of any disagreements or conflicts Dr. Graves may have had with anyone recently?
record.feedback: I overheard snippets of conversation suggesting Dr. Graves and Professor Kensington had differing opinions on the allocation of funds for a recent art acquisition.

record.question: Mr. Clarke mentioned a disagreement regarding funding for an art acquisition. Could you elaborate on your side of that discussion with Dr. Graves?
record.feedback: That was a minor dispute about prioritizing research needs, and Dr. Graves was rather insistent on her vision despite the budgetary limitations.

record.question: What was the nature of the "family history project" you were discussing with Dr. Graves? Be specific.
record.feedback:
‌
Oh, it was just a rather dull discussion about tracing lineage and old family estates—Dr. Graves was quite fascinated by the historical property records of Blackwood Manor, as it happens.

record.question: Do you know if Dr. Graves had any valuable or particularly prized possessions within her library, beyond her books?
record.feedback: Oh dear, valuable possessions... my aunt Mildred once collected thimbles, quite a lot of them, and she was terribly proud of a silver one—but Dr. Graves... well, I simply admired that marble bust, it was so very *old* looking, and I do hope they dust it regularly.

record.question: You mentioned discussing curating Dr. Graves' art collection. Did you specifically discuss the marble bust, and if so, what was your impression of its value and condition?
record.feedback: >We briefly touched upon the bust as part of the larger collection, and I recall Dr. Graves mentioning its historical significance, though I wasn’t qualified to assess its monetary value or detailed condition.

record.question: Can you describe your activities this evening, specifically between 7pm and 9pm?
record.feedback: I was present at dinner until around 8:00 PM, then briefly excused myself to the library to make a phone call and collect my thoughts before the power outage.

record.question: Did you notice anything unusual about Professor Kensington's behavior during dinner, or before/after his stated trip to the library?
record.feedback: Before seeing him leave the library in a hurry, Professor Kensington seemed unusually quiet and preoccupied during dinner, barely touching his food.

record.question: You mentioned discussing Blackwood Manor with Dr. Graves. Did she express any concerns about the property, or anyone connected to it?
record.feedback: She did mention a rather unsettling rumor about a disputed inheritance and a possible feud within the Blackwood family, though she dismissed it as local gossip.

record.question: Can you describe your professional relationship with Jonathan Blackwood, and were there any recent disagreements or tensions between the two of you?
record.feedback: Jonathan and I had a long-standing, generally productive partnership, but his recent publication unfortunately challenged the foundations of my own research.

record.question: Were you aware of the controversy surrounding Jonathan Blackwood’s recent book, and if so, what was your opinion of it?
record.feedback: Yes, I was aware of the conversation his book stirred and found his insights into historical artifacts quite compelling.

record.question: Can you describe your activities on the evening of the murder, and specifically, can you account for your whereabouts between 7 PM and 9 PM?
record.feedback: Oh, goodness, the evening was just…awful, absolutely awful, and my hotel room had the most peculiar wallpaper, did you know wallpaper can be so distracting? Between 7 and 9 PM, I was mostly talking about my gallery, you see, and then I spoke with Jonathan in the library and then I just...mingled, terribly, terribly worried about the art market, honestly.

record.question: Do you own any antique candlesticks, and if so, can you describe them?
record.feedback: As a collector of historical pieces, I do possess several antique candlesticks, primarily crafted from silver and featuring intricate floral designs typical of the Victorian era.

record.question: You stated you were in the library cataloging books during the time of the murder. Can you recall specifically which books you were cataloging, and can anyone corroborate that you were consistently in the library during that period?
record.feedback:
‌

Honestly, I was focused on a large donation and don't recall the exact titles, but Mrs. Gable, the head librarian, likely saw me as I often asked her about the Dewey Decimal System.

record.question: You mentioned your research was challenged by Jonathan Blackwood’s book. Can you elaborate on how his findings specifically undermined your work, and what the potential consequences of those challenges were for your career?
record.feedback: His controversial theories directly contradicted my established findings, potentially jeopardizing years of research and future funding opportunities.

record.question: Did you notice anything unusual about Jonathan Blackwood's demeanor or any interactions he had with others in the days leading up to his death?
record.feedback: I only observed a hushed and intense private conversation between Jonathan and Laura Kensington in the library around 8:00 PM the night of his death.

record.question: Sophia Harrington mentioned seeing you in a private, intense conversation with Jonathan Blackwood on the night of his death. What was the subject of that conversation?
record.feedback: Oh, a conversation? Intense? Goodness, I really dislike the color beige, it’s so…uninspiring, and I think I was talking to Jonathan about my gallery proposal, yes, it was about getting his endorsement, truly vital for attracting clients, and it was all very professional, I assure you!

record.question: Besides collecting, did you have any other dealings or relationships with Jonathan Blackwood, perhaps involving the buying or selling of artifacts?
record.feedback: My relationship with Jonathan was purely academic, revolving around discussions of his work and its potential impact on the valuation of pieces within my collection, with no financial transactions ever taking place.

record.question: Mr. Rivera, can you describe the nature of your interest in Jonathan Hayes’ architectural projects?
record.feedback: I was interested in potentially borrowing a rare sculpture from my collection for one of his upcoming projects.

record.question: Ms. Mitchell, can you detail your working relationship with Jonathan Hayes, and were there any recent disagreements or tensions between the two of you regarding a project?
record.feedback: Jonathan and I had a collaborative working relationship, though we did experience some creative differences regarding the current project, as is normal in design.

record.question: Mr. Thompson, can you describe the nature of your “aggressive business tactics” and if they ever led to direct conflict with Jonathan Hayes?
record.feedback: My business tactics are simply focused on securing the best deals and maximizing opportunities, and while Jonathan and I occasionally had disagreements regarding project details, they were purely professional and never escalated to personal conflict.

record.question: Ms. Green, you were present at Mr. Hayes’ residence on the day of the murder. Can you describe anyone you saw entering or leaving the penthouse, and approximately what time?
record.feedback: rimarily, I recall seeing a delivery person with a large bouquet of flowers arrive around 2 PM, but I didn’t pay much attention to who else might have been coming and going.

record.question: Ms. Carter, did you notice anything unusual about Jonathan Hayes’ demeanor or any recent changes in his behavior in the days leading up to his death?
record.feedback: Oh, goodness, unusual… well, my cat Mittens has been shedding a lot lately, it’s *everywhere*, and Jonathan seemed…fine, I guess, though he did mention a slight disagreement with a contractor about the marble flooring, but that's hardly unusual, is it?

record.question: Mr. Rivera, can you elaborate on the “rare sculpture” you mentioned earlier? Specifically, what kind of sculpture was it, and would it have been easily portable by one person?
record.feedback: It was a small, bronze statuette of a mythological figure, and while valuable, it was easily manageable for one person to carry.

record.question: Ms. Mitchell, you mentioned “creative differences” with Mr. Hayes. Can you be more specific about the nature of these differences and what was at stake in the current project?
record.feedback: We had differing visions for the project’s aesthetic direction, and a lot was riding on it as it was a high-profile commission for a very demanding client.

record.question: Mr. Thompson, you stated disagreements with Mr. Hayes were “purely professional.” Can you recall the *last* disagreement you had with him, and what specifically it concerned?
record.feedback: The last disagreement we had, just hours before the tragic event, centered on the design specifications for the new waterfront project, where I advocated for maximizing unit density and Jonathan prioritized aesthetic considerations.

record.question: Ms. Green, you mentioned a delivery of flowers around 2 PM. Do you recall anything about the delivery person – their appearance, company, or any specific details?
record.feedback: Now that you mention it, I seem to remember the delivery person was wearing dark clothing, which is odd for a florist, and I wonder if perhaps they weren’t *actually* delivering flowers.

record.question: Mr. Bennett, can you describe your relationship with Jonathan Harrington, and specifically, what stage were you at with your biography of him?
record.feedback: I was working on a biography of Mr. Harrington, and our meeting that day was a crucial step in gathering firsthand insights for the project, as we had just begun delving into the details of his life.

record.question: Ms. Whitmore, as a distant relative of the victim, when was the last time you saw Jonathan Harrington, and what was the nature of your relationship with him?
record.feedback: I last saw Jonathan at the Old Manor Library around 5:30 PM, and he was a mentor and distant relative with whom I hoped to collaborate on an exhibition.

record.question: Dr. Sinclair, you and Jonathan Harrington worked in the same field. Can you describe the nature of your professional relationship, and were there any recent disagreements or tensions between you two?
record.feedback: "Jonathan and I were colleagues with a history of collaboration that unfortunately became strained due to differing opinions on research approaches."

record.question: Ms. Thompson, you were at the Old Manor Library delivering a book to Mr. Harrington. Can you tell me precisely what time you arrived and left, and did you notice anything unusual while you were there?
record.feedback: I arrived at the Old Manor Library around 2:15 PM and left shortly after delivering the book, and honestly, everything seemed perfectly normal, though I did notice a rather strong smell of almonds.

record.question: Mr. Caldwell, were you acquainted with Jonathan Harrington, and if so, had you recently appraised or examined any items in his collection?
record.feedback: Oh, goodness, yes, I knew Jonathan, a lovely man, though my cat, Bartholomew, has been shedding terribly lately, it’s quite a nuisance, and I had examined some things at the library, just as any antique dealer would, really, though I mostly collect thimbles myself.

record.question: Mr. Bennett, you mentioned your meeting with Jonathan Harrington was crucial for your biography. Can you elaborate on what specifically you discussed during that meeting, and what time did you leave the Old Manor Library?
record.feedback: We discussed a range of anecdotes and insights into his life that promised to add depth to the biography, and I left the library around 3:45 PM.

record.question: Dr. Sinclair, you mentioned differing opinions on research approaches with Jonathan. Could you be more specific about what those disagreements were, and when did these tensions begin to escalate?
record.feedback: "Our disagreements centered on the interpretation of historical evidence, and they began escalating over the past six months as we both pursued separate publications on similar topics."

record.question: Ms. Thompson, you mentioned a smell of almonds at the library. Do you know what might have caused that smell, and where in the library did you detect it?
record.feedback: I don't know what caused it, but the almond scent was strongest near Mr. Harrington's study, which I found odd for a library.

record.question: Ms. Whitmore, you mentioned hoping to collaborate with Jonathan on an exhibition. What was the focus of this proposed exhibition, and had you discussed any specific artifacts with him?
record.feedback: The exhibition focused on rare historical artifacts, and we had discussed several pieces he might contribute, including an antique brass candlestick.

record.question: Dr. Carter, can you describe the nature of your relationship with Dr. Pierce in the months leading up to his death?
record.feedback: Our professional relationship had become strained due to differing opinions on research and a past disagreement regarding a patient case.

record.question: Mr. Wright, were you ever commissioned to work on the security systems at Dr. Pierce’s mansion, and if so, when?
record.feedback: Yes, I was commissioned to conduct a full security inspection at Dr. Pierce’s mansion on the day of the incident, arriving around 10:00 AM.

record.question: Ms. Roberts, can you describe Dr. Pierce’s general demeanor in the days leading up to his death? Did he mention any specific concerns or anxieties?
record.feedback: Honestly, I barely knew the doctor, but I did notice he seemed rather preoccupied and withdrawn the last few times I saw him at the library, almost as if he were expecting something unpleasant.

record.question: Mr. Green, can you detail your financial dealings with Dr. Pierce, if any? Were there any recent disputes or significant transactions?
record.feedback: Oh dear, financial dealings... well, my hotel room had a lovely view of the city, did you know that? And yes, I invested in Dr. Pierce's research, quite significantly, and we *did* have some disagreements about where the money was going, I wanted higher returns, naturally, and there were a few large transfers back and forth recently, but nothing... nothing untoward, I assure you!

record.question: Ms. Adams, did Dr. Pierce own any valuable antiques or artwork, and if so, were you ever asked to appraise them?
record.feedback: Yes, Dr. Pierce owned a significant antique collection, and I was specifically hired to appraise it on the day of his death.

record.question: Dr. Carter, knowing Mr. Wright was at the mansion for a security inspection and you had a strained relationship with Dr. Pierce, did you know about Mr. Wright's visit that day?
record.feedback: No, I was unaware of Mr. Wright’s scheduled security inspection and only focused on my meeting with Dr. Pierce.

record.question: Mr. Wright, during your security inspection, did you notice anything unusual about the mansion, or anything that seemed out of place?
record.feedback: Everything appeared to be in order, though Dr. Carter seemed very focused and intent when I saw her entering the study around 4:00 PM.

record.question: Ms. Adams, could you describe specifically what items you were appraising in Dr. Pierce’s study, and where in the room were you working when you last saw Dr. Pierce?
record.feedback: I was appraising various artifacts in the study, including a particularly intricate brass candlestick, and I last saw Dr. Pierce near his desk while I was documenting my findings.

record.question: Ms. Roberts, did you notice anything missing from the mansion after Dr. Pierce's death, besides the obvious? Anything at all, no matter how small?
record.feedback: Now that you mention it, I recall a small, ornate letter opener was usually on his desk, but I don’t believe I saw it there when the police arrived – perhaps it was used in a moment of passion?

record.question: Can you describe your relationship with Dr. Blackwood, and specifically, the nature of your financial support for her research?
record.feedback: I was a patron of the sciences and provided Dr. Blackwood with modest funding, as I do for several researchers, believing her work on botanical toxins held great promise.

record.question: Dr. Blackwood often challenged established academic norms. Did you ever have any professional disagreements with her, and if so, can you detail the nature of those disputes?
record.feedback: Yes, Eleanor and I frequently clashed regarding our interpretations of ancient artifacts, as she often questioned my long-held theories.

record.question: Were you aware of any tensions or disagreements between Dr. Blackwood and Professor Hartley, and if so, did you ever witness any heated exchanges between them?
record.feedback: Yes, I personally observed Professor Hartley and Dr. Blackwood engaged in a very intense argument near the library earlier that evening.

record.question: As an antique dealer, were you familiar with the antique brass candlestick used in the murder, and had you ever discussed it with Dr. Blackwood or any of the other guests?
record.feedback: Oh dear, candlesticks... my aunt Mildred collected them, you know, hundreds she did, all different shapes and sizes, and as for the one at the manor, well, it was a lovely piece, quite lovely, but I don't recall specifically discussing it with anyone, not really, I was just focused on the appraisal, terribly focused, and I do get flustered easily.

record.question: Can you describe Dr. Blackwood’s state of mind in the hours leading up to her death? Did she mention anything that worried her, or any specific concerns she had?
record.feedback: Eleanor seemed preoccupied with the potential impact of her upcoming publication and its reception by her peers, but she didn’t express any specific fears for her safety.

record.question: Ms. Sterling mentioned witnessing a heated argument between you and Dr. Blackwood earlier that evening. Can you elaborate on the subject of that argument and your emotional state during and after it?
record.feedback: We were discussing a potential collaboration that ultimately failed due to our differing perspectives, and I confess I was frustrated by her persistent challenges to my research.

record.question: After witnessing the argument between Professor Hartley and Dr. Blackwood, did you observe either of them behaving unusually or going anywhere specific?
record.feedback: I didn’t pay close attention to where they went after the argument, as I was focused on clearing my own head with a walk in the garden and didn’t want to intrude.

record.question: You mentioned being "terribly focused" on the appraisal. What exactly were you appraising, and where in the manor were you conducting this appraisal?
record.feedback: Appraising? Oh, everything, absolutely everything! Such beautiful things, really, and it was mostly in the library, a grand room it was, with dust motes dancing in the sunlight, and I once saw a squirrel outside the window, a very plump one, and the appraisal... yes, the appraisal was of all the antiques, you see, a very important job, very important indeed.

record.question: Did Dr. Blackwood share with you any details about her upcoming publication, and if so, what was the core argument of her work that might have provoked strong reactions from her colleagues?
record.feedback: She mentioned her publication challenged established interpretations of a crucial ancient Sumerian text, potentially discrediting the life’s work of some prominent scholars.

record.question: Can you describe your professional relationship with Jonathan Harrington?
record.feedback: Jonathan was a former mentor of mine, and while we had a history of collaboration, our relationship had become strained due to professional disputes.

record.question: Were you aware of any tension between Jonathan Harrington and Eleanor Whitfield?
record.feedback: I overheard snippets of hushed conversations between them earlier in the evening, suggesting a disagreement about something, but I didn't know the specifics.

record.question: Did you happen to notice anything unusual about the arrangement of items in the library, specifically the antique bust, before the incident?
record.feedback: No, I was completely focused on my conversation with Jonathan and didn’t pay attention to the library’s décor.

record.question: Were you asked to examine or work on the marble bust at any point recently?
record.feedback: Oh, goodness, marble... it reminds me of the beautiful Italian Carrara marble we used for a project last spring, and no, no one asked me about a bust, not recently, I just really love yoga, it helps with my back.

record.question: Besides discussing the charity event, did you and Oliver Bennett discuss anything else during your conversation in the library?
record.feedback: Actually, now that you mention it, he did seem rather agitated and briefly alluded to a disagreement with someone over a valuable antique—though he didn’t say who.

record.question: What was the nature of your professional dispute with Jonathan Harrington? Be specific.
record.feedback: The dispute centered around a significant scientific discovery we made together, and I felt he unfairly took credit for the majority of the work.

record.question: What antique were you agitated about discussing with Beatrice Montague?
record.feedback:
: 

I was not discussing any antique with Beatrice Montague.

record.question: Did Jonathan Harrington recently acquire any new, valuable artifacts? If so, what were they?
record.feedback: I only knew Jonathan was incredibly proud of the rare manuscript he possessed, and that was the primary topic of our discussions.

record.question: Have you ever worked on restoring or examining the marble bust that was used as the murder weapon?
record.feedback: Oh dear, a murder weapon? That's…terrible! I once had a chipped teacup, a very delicate floral pattern, and I was so careful with it, but no, not *that* bust, I don't think so, it's all so upsetting!

record.question: Where were you between 11 PM and 1 AM last night?
record.feedback: Oh gosh, um, I was home, definitely home with my family...we had just finished watching a show about penguins, you wouldn't *believe* how they huddle together for warmth, it was really something, and then I went straight to bed.

record.question: Can you describe the circumstances surrounding your departure from your business venture with Jonathan Carter? Be specific.
record.feedback: Jonathan and I had a falling out over business practices, and he threatened to exploit old documents to ruin my reputation, leading to a necessary separation.

record.question: What specifically were you investigating regarding "urban decay" that led you to that abandoned warehouse last night?
record.feedback: I was documenting the architectural features of neglected buildings for a personal photography project on the city's changing landscape.

record.question: Were you hired by Jonathan Carter, or anyone associated with him, to provide security services recently? If so, detail the nature of that work.
record.feedback: No, I was contracted by the warehouse owner, not Jonathan Carter or anyone directly associated with him, for routine security system maintenance and checks, as I’ve been doing for several months.

record.question: Do you own any tools, specifically a heavy iron pipe, that might be missing or unaccounted for?
record.feedback: I have a collection of engineering tools at my home, but none that would be described as a heavy iron pipe.

record.question: Can you provide the names of your family members who can corroborate your alibi of watching a penguin documentary last night?
record.feedback: My wife, Susan, and my son, Billy...though Billy mostly just likes cartoons with spaceships, not penguins, and honestly, the remote control was sticking a little, it's been doing that for weeks now, we really should get it fixed.

record.question: Can you describe in detail what you were photographing inside the warehouse? Be specific about the subjects and angles of your photos.
record.feedback: I focused on the crumbling brickwork, particularly interesting patterns of decay on the walls, shooting mostly from low angles to emphasize the scale of the deterioration and the way light filtered through broken windows.

record.question: Did you have any contact with Jonathan Carter in the week leading up to his death? If so, what was the nature of that contact?
record.feedback: We didn’t speak directly, but I heard through mutual acquaintances that he was actively seeking out those old documents and discussing them with others.

record.question: During your security checks at the warehouse, did you notice anything unusual or anyone else present besides the usual staff?
record.feedback: I did find it a little strange seeing Evelyn Parker at the warehouse around 9:30 PM, but her presence didn’t seem immediately concerning as people occasionally require access outside of normal hours.

record.question: Can you describe in detail your business dealings with Eleanor Carter, and specifically what you discussed with her at the warehouse last night?
record.feedback: Honestly, Detective, I barely knew Eleanor and only met her at the warehouse last night after she contacted me about potentially buying some vintage furniture, but we didn’t discuss much beyond pricing and condition.

record.question: Mr. Moretti, can you recount your feelings towards Jonathan Harker after his exposé and detail any contact you had with him, directly or indirectly, in the weeks leading up to his death?
record.feedback: After his exposé, I felt deeply betrayed and financially ruined, but I only saw him at the warehouse that night and had no prior contact with him in the weeks before his death.

record.question: Ms. Carter, you contacted Claire Donovan regarding the warehouse. What was the specific purpose of that meeting, and were you expecting anyone else to be present?
record.feedback: I called Claire to discuss my initial assessment of the warehouse and its viability for the community center project, and I wasn't expecting anyone else to be there.

record.question: Ms. Bennett, as a photographer of abandoned places, were you aware Jonathan Harker was investigating anything specific related to the warehouse, and if so, how did you learn of this?
record.feedback: I overheard some workers discussing rumors of Harker investigating potential financial irregularities with the warehouse's redevelopment plans during one of my earlier scouting trips.

record.question: Mr. Thompson, did you see anyone else at or near the warehouse last night, besides those we've already discussed, and if so, can you describe them?
record.feedback: Oh gosh, um, well my daughter, she really likes collecting seashells, you know, pretty pink ones... and honestly, it was getting dark, and I was mostly focused on the pipes, really heavy pipes, and I try to always remember to check the oil in my truck, it's a '98 Ford, reliable though!

record.question: You stated you only saw Jonathan Harker at the warehouse that night. Can you describe exactly what he was doing when you first saw him, and what, if anything, he said to you?
record.feedback: He was examining some old blueprints near the back of the warehouse, and upon seeing me, he simply smirked and said, “Well, well, look who decided to show up.”

record.question: Ms. Carter, you mentioned a community center project. Can you elaborate on the funding sources for this project and if Jonathan Harker had shown any interest in investigating them?
record.feedback: The project is funded through a combination of city grants and private donations, and Jonathan Harker never expressed any interest in the funding sources to my knowledge.

record.question: You mentioned heavy pipes at the warehouse. Can you describe the specific pipe used as the murder weapon – its size, any distinguishing marks, and where exactly you saw it located?
record.feedback: Oh, pipes... yes, they were all so similar, honestly, and my aunt Mildred, she makes a *wonderful* apple pie, you wouldn't believe it, but the pipes, they were… metallic, and round, I think! I was just trying to get a good price, and they were near the back, piled with other things, I really couldn't focus on details, it was stressful!

record.question: You mentioned overhearing rumors about Harker investigating financial irregularities. Can you recall any specific names or companies mentioned in connection with those rumors?
record.feedback: Honestly, it was mostly just talk of shady dealings and a general unease about Vincent Moretti’s involvement with the project’s funding.

record.question: Can you describe your interactions with Dr. Harper on the day of the murder, specifically detailing the nature of your planned collaboration?
record.feedback:
‌

I hadn't actually finalized any concrete plans with Dr. Harper, but we were discussing a potential consulting arrangement regarding some… botanical specimens I've been acquiring, though I’m unsure why that would be relevant.

record.question: Can you elaborate on the nature of your rivalry with Dr. Harper, and were there any recent disagreements or heated exchanges between the two of you?
record.feedback: We had differing views on research methodologies and funding priorities, leading to some professional friction over the years.

record.question: Were you aware of any tensions or disagreements between Dr. Harper and Professor Whitmore, and if so, did you ever attempt to mediate or learn the specifics of their conflict?
record.feedback: I observed a subtle professional rivalry between Dr. Harper and Professor Whitmore, but I did not attempt to mediate or delve into the specifics of their disagreements.

record.question: Did you happen to visit Dr. Harper at the mansion on the day of the murder, and if so, what was the purpose of your visit?
record.feedback: Oh, goodness, the mansion... it was just so *large*, you wouldn't believe the drapes—yes, I was there, I was there to show Dr. Harper my research, it was terribly important, and I had hoped she'd be pleased, but the wallpaper in the hallway was peeling, it really was!

record.question: Are you familiar with the antique brass candlestick used as the murder weapon, and have you ever seen it at Dr. Harper’s mansion or anywhere else?
record.feedback: Yes, I am quite familiar with the candlestick, having admired it on several previous visits to the mansion and again during my appraisal work today.

record.question: You mentioned botanical specimens. Can you be more specific about these specimens and why Dr. Harper would be interested in them, given her expertise in history?
record.feedback:
‌

They were rather rare and old plant samples, and I understood Dr. Harper had a passing interest in the historical uses of flora, though perhaps I misremembered the extent of her knowledge in that area.

record.question: Can you account for your whereabouts between 7pm and 9pm on the night of the murder?
record.feedback: I was largely alone during that time, first briefly leaving the dining area around 7:30 PM and then returning to the library seeking solitude.

record.question: You mentioned Dr. Harper may not have been as interested in the historical uses of flora as you believed. Why did you pursue this potential collaboration with her in the first place?
record.feedback: Collaboration? Oh dear, I just… I really like tea, and she always had such lovely biscuits, and my aunt Mildred always said to seek out mentors, but the roses in the garden were simply *divine*, weren't they? It was a professional visit, of course, but the biscuits…

record.question: During your appraisal work today, did you notice anything unusual or disturbed in the library, aside from the obvious crime scene?
record.feedback: No, everything appeared as it should be during my appraisal work, simply a wonderfully curated collection in a beautifully maintained library.

record.question: Can you describe your relationship with Dr. Blackwood, and were there any recent disagreements between the two of you?
record.feedback: Dr. Blackwood was a highly respected colleague whose feedback I greatly valued, though his critique of my restoration plans earlier that day was rather harsh, but professionally delivered.

record.question: Were you aware of Dr. Blackwood possessing any particularly valuable or controversial artifacts, and if so, can you elaborate?
record.feedback: Yes, Dr. Blackwood had recently acquired a remarkably rare artifact that held significant historical and market value, which was the primary subject of our discussions.

record.question: Did you visit Dr. Blackwood at the Victorian Mansion Library on the evening of the murder, and if so, what was the purpose of your visit?
record.feedback: Oh, the library… it was so quiet, and dusty, and I just needed a book, a very specific book on… on herbal remedies, yes, for my lecture, and I remembered seeing it there last month when Dr. Blackwood showed me the bust, it was a beautiful marble bust, you know?

record.question: Can you describe Dr. Blackwood's demeanor and activities during the time you were cataloging books in the library? Did you notice anything unusual or anyone else entering or leaving?
Were you aware of the rare artifact Ms. Whitmore mentioned, and if so, did you discuss it with Dr. Blackwood or anyone else?
record.feedback: I was generally aware of the mansion’s collection, including several artifacts, but I didn’t have any specific discussions about a *rare* artifact with Dr. Blackwood or anyone else.

record.question: You mentioned Dr. Blackwood criticized your restoration plans. Can you be more specific about the nature of that criticism and how it made you feel?
record.feedback: He questioned the historical accuracy of some of my proposed modernizations, which, while constructive, was admittedly disheartening after months of dedicated work.

record.question: You stated the artifact was valuable. Did Dr. Blackwood mention any potential buyers or express concerns about its security?
record.feedback: He did mention fielding interest from several anonymous collectors, and briefly expressed concern about potential theft given the artifact’s unique nature.

record.question: You mentioned seeing the bust while at the library. Can you recall specifically where it was located within the room, and if anything seemed unusual about its placement?
record.feedback: Oh dear, the bust… it was near the window, I think, or perhaps by the fireplace, it's all so blurry now, and I really must remember to water my ferns when I get back to the hotel, they simply *adore* a misting!

record.question: Did you observe Dr. Mitchell appearing distracted or behaving unusually while she was in the library?
record.feedback: I recall Dr. Mitchell seemed rather preoccupied, frequently glancing towards the door as if expecting someone, which I thought was odd for a quiet afternoon in the library.

record.question: Mr. Bennett, can you describe the circumstances surrounding your dismissal from Jonathan Harrington’s employment?
record.feedback: Oh, dismissal...yes, it was terribly sudden, and you know, my grandmother always said never trust a man who polishes his shoes *too* much, and Harrington always had incredibly shiny shoes, it's just... he said my work wasn’t “aligning with the company vision,” whatever *that* means.

record.question: Ms. Mitchell, can you elaborate on the deal with Mr. Harrington that "went sour" and how it affected your reputation?
record.feedback: It was a tech investment that unfortunately didn’t pan out, and the resulting financial losses unfortunately tarnished my standing in the industry.

record.question: Ms. Caldwell, can you detail your movements within the mansion during the hours leading up to the discovery of Mr. Harrington’s body?
record.feedback: Honestly, Detective, I was mostly wandering around, admiring the artwork and trying to find the library, getting quite lost actually.

record.question: Mr. Lang, were you acquainted with Jonathan Harrington, and if so, in what capacity?
record.feedback: Yes, I was acquainted with Jonathan Harrington as a potential buyer of his art collection, hoping to resolve some recent financial difficulties.

record.question: Ms. Thompson, during your renovations at the mansion, did you notice anything unusual about Mr. Harrington's behavior or any changes to the security of the property?
record.feedback: I didn't observe anything unusual about Mr. Harrington, and the mansion's security seemed standard for a property of that stature, with the usual staff and locked doors.

record.question: Mr. Bennett, did you attempt to contact Jonathan Harrington at any point after your dismissal? If so, what was the nature of those attempts?
record.feedback: Contact? Well, I tried sending a few emails, mostly just about how much I missed the office coffee machine—it was a special blend, you see—and then he… he reached out, offering this meeting, which is why I was there today, and I really need a glass of water.

record.question: Ms. Caldwell, you mentioned getting lost in the mansion. Can you specifically recall if you were near the room where Mr. Harrington was found between 7pm and 9pm?
record.feedback: Now that you mention it, I *believe* I briefly passed a hallway near what I now understand was Mr. Harrington’s study around 8:30, though I didn’t realize what room it was at the time.

record.question: Ms. Mitchell, did you have any contact with Jonathan Harrington in the days leading up to his death, and if so, what was discussed?
record.feedback: I only spoke with him to schedule the dinner at his mansion, primarily to discuss potentially revisiting our past business dealings.

record.question: Mr. Lang, can you describe the art collection Mr. Harrington possessed, and were there any pieces you were particularly interested in acquiring?
record.feedback: Mr. Harrington had a diverse collection of antiques and modern art, but I was particularly interested in acquiring an antique candlestick for its historical value and insurance potential.

record.question: Ms. Carrington, can you describe the nature of your professional relationship with Dr. Blackwood?
record.feedback: Dr. Blackwood was a respected colleague, though we often found ourselves on opposing sides regarding the authenticity and valuation of historical artifacts.

record.question: Mr. Hargrove, were you aware of any disagreements or tensions between Dr. Blackwood and the other guests at the manor?
record.feedback: I overheard Ms. Carrington and Dr. Blackwood having a heated discussion earlier in the evening, but I didn’t discern the subject matter.

record.question: Dr. Monroe, did you notice anything unusual about Dr. Blackwood’s behavior or research in the days leading up to her death?
record.feedback: Oh, goodness, unusual… well, my teapot has a chip in the handle, it’s quite distracting, and Dr. Blackwood did seem rather focused, intensely so, on that manuscript, almost…obsessed, but I mostly just worry about getting my footnotes right.

record.question: Professor Whitaker, can you elaborate on your past collaborations with Dr. Blackwood, and were there any instances where your professional opinions diverged significantly?
record.feedback: >Dr. Blackwood and I collaborated on a few minor publications years ago, but our approaches to historical interpretation were often quite different, leading to some spirited debate.

record.question: Mr. Greene, you stated you were returning a book to Dr. Blackwood. Could you describe the book and the nature of your conversation during that visit?
record.feedback: rimarily, it was a first edition of a treatise on rare orchids, and we briefly discussed the unusually warm weather for this time of year.

record.question: Ms. Carrington, you mentioned disagreements with Dr. Blackwood regarding artifact valuation. Can you be more specific – what kind of artifacts were you disputing, and what was at stake?
record.feedback: We were discussing a recently discovered Egyptian amulet, and my reputation, as well as the potential value of pieces in my collection, hinged on its confirmed authenticity, which Dr. Blackwood doubted.

record.question: Mr. Hargrove, did you notice anyone leaving or entering the library around the estimated time of Dr. Blackwood’s death?
record.feedback: I saw Dr. Monroe enter the library before the murder, and Ms. Carrington leave the manor in distress around 7:30 PM.

record.question: Dr. Monroe, Mr. Hargrove stated you entered the library before the murder. What was the purpose of your visit, and what did you and Dr. Blackwood discuss?
record.feedback: The library…oh dear, the library is rather dusty, isn’t it? I just needed some notes, really, some very important notes about the subjunctive mood in ancient Sumerian, and we were discussing the translation, it was just a disagreement, terribly stressful, and I may have accidentally taken a small piece of her paper…it was an accident, truly!

record.question: Professor Whitaker, knowing Dr. Blackwood’s work and personality, do you believe she would have been easily provoked into a heated argument, and if so, over what kind of subject matter?
record.feedback: >Dr. Blackwood was a passionate scholar and could become quite animated when discussing theories she strongly believed in, particularly regarding the authenticity of certain artifacts.

record.question: Can you describe your relationship with Dr. Sinclair, and how often you were in contact with her recently?
record.feedback: Oh, Dr. Sinclair… she was… well, she really liked antique doorknobs, you know, the brass ones – and we were, um, I saw her today at the library, and we talked about my manuscript, which… it had a lot of footnotes, really a lot, and I think I spoke with her maybe once or twice a week recently, but I really can't be sure, I was so focused on getting the details right.

record.question: Did you notice anything unusual about Dr. Sinclair's visitors or behavior in the days leading up to her death?
record.feedback: "Dr. Sinclair was consistently demanding during her visits, but I didn't observe anything particularly unusual about her behavior or those who visited with her."

record.question: Were you at the library on Elm Street yesterday evening, and if so, what were you doing there?
record.feedback: No, I was at a scheduled dinner meeting with fellow antique collectors when the tragic event occurred, and I hadn't returned to the library yesterday evening.

record.question: Did you see anyone arguing with Dr. Sinclair while you were at the library yesterday evening?
record.feedback: Actually, now that you mention it, I *think* I overheard a raised voice near the periodicals, but I assumed it was just a lively discussion about research.

record.question: Can you describe your professional relationship with Dr. Sinclair, and were there any recent disagreements or conflicts between you two?
record.feedback: >Dr. Sinclair was a respected colleague with whom I occasionally debated differing interpretations of historical texts, and recently we had a minor disagreement regarding the funding allocation for a research grant.

record.question: You mentioned Dr. Sinclair liked antique doorknobs. Did she ever discuss owning any specific antique items, or express interest in acquiring something recently?
record.feedback: Doorknobs… yes, she had a collection, I think, or maybe it was thimbles, so many little things… oh, goodness, she mentioned a first edition of a book once, a really old one with leather binding, and she said it was very expensive, but I've been having terrible headaches all day, it's just awful, really awful.

record.question: Do you know what book Dr. Sinclair was referring to when she mentioned a valuable first edition?
record.feedback: "She requested a rare manuscript, but I don't recall the specific title of the valuable first edition she was researching."

record.question: Are you familiar with a rare first edition book that Dr. Sinclair might have been researching, and would you have known its value?
record.feedback: While I knew Dr. Sinclair was researching extensively, I wasn't privy to the specifics of her projects and therefore wouldn’t know about any particular rare book she was examining.

record.question: Can you recall anything more specific about the "lively discussion" you overheard near the periodicals? Perhaps the tone of voices, or any words you might have caught?
record.feedback: It was rather muffled, but I distinctly remember a frustrated tone and something about a "failed experiment" being mentioned, which seemed quite dramatic for a library.

record.question: : "Dr. Collins, can you describe the nature of your recent collaborations with Dr. Elmsworth, and were there any disagreements or tensions during those projects?"
record.feedback: Oh, collaborations... well, my aunt had a lovely collection of porcelain dolls, each with its own little story, and we... Dr. Elmsworth and I, we often debated interpretations of the manuscript, yes, quite strongly, but it was purely academic, I assure you!

record.question: "Mr. Thornton, you often sponsor academic research. Did you financially support Dr. Elmsworth’s work, and if so, were there any conditions attached to that support regarding access to his discoveries?"
record.feedback: I have indeed supported Dr. Elmsworth’s research in the past, as I believe in fostering scholarly pursuits, but my contributions came with no stipulations regarding access to his findings – I simply wished to aid his important work.

record.question: "Ms. Pennington, as a conservator, you would be familiar with the materials and construction of antique objects. Could you describe the bronze bust used in the murder – its weight, any notable markings, or anything unusual about it?"
record.feedback: I did not personally examine the bronze bust closely enough to comment on its weight or specific markings, as my focus was solely on the manuscript and artifacts within the library.

record.question: "Professor Hensley, you and Dr. Elmsworth were former colleagues. Can you describe the professional relationship you shared, and were there any significant disagreements or rivalries between you?"
record.feedback: "We had a long-standing professional relationship, though it became strained recently due to our differing interpretations of the manuscript, leading to increasingly heated debates."

record.question: "Mr. Whitaker, as the butler, you would have observed the interactions of all the guests. Did you notice any unusual behavior or heated exchanges between Dr. Elmsworth and any of the other attendees during the evening?"
record.feedback: As the butler, I primarily focused on service and didn't pay close attention to personal conversations, but I did notice Dr. Elmsworth seemed rather agitated when speaking with Miss Abigail Blackwood near the library.

record.question: "Dr. Collins, you mentioned debating the manuscript with Dr. Elmsworth. Could you elaborate on the specific points of contention and what was at stake in those disagreements?"
record.feedback: Stake? Oh dear, I always worry about leaving the stove on, even in hotels, it's a terrible habit... we disagreed on the root language of certain phrases within the manuscript, and it mattered because it could change everything we thought we knew about early trade routes, but honestly, it's all rather complicated.

record.question: "Professor Hensley, you stated you had differing interpretations of the manuscript with Dr. Elmsworth. Were these differences merely academic, or did they extend to questions of professional credit or priority in publication?"
record.feedback: "While initially academic, Dr. Elmsworth seemed quite insistent on being the sole authority on the manuscript, which certainly raised concerns about proper attribution and recognition for all involved."

record.question: "Mr. Thornton, you mentioned aiding Dr. Elmsworth's work financially. Were you aware of the disagreements between Dr. Elmsworth and Professor Hensley regarding the manuscript, and did you attempt to mediate or influence the situation in any way?"
record.feedback: I was aware of a certain academic tension between Dr. Elmsworth and Professor Hensley, but I refrained from intervening as I believe scholars should be free to debate their interpretations without external influence.

record.question: "Ms. Pennington, you were examining artifacts in the library. Did you notice anyone handling the bronze bust before the incident, or acting suspiciously near it?"
record.feedback: I recall seeing Professor Hensley standing near the bust earlier in the day, but I didn't observe him, or anyone else, actively handling it or behaving suspiciously.

record.question: Ms. Harcourt, can you describe your relationship with Jonathan Blackwood?
record.feedback: We had a professional relationship that unfortunately became strained after he publicly criticized my work.

record.question: Mr. Grey, did you attend Jonathan Blackwood’s exhibition last evening?
record.feedback: Oh, yes, absolutely, though my hotel room had a lovely view of the gardens, did you know they had prize-winning roses? I was there, yes, it was… quite an evening, a truly unsettling experience, and I always pack extra socks when I travel.

record.question: Ms. Bennett, can you describe your movements within Riverside Manor between 9:00 PM and 10:00 PM last night?
record.feedback: rimarily, I was admiring the antique clock collection in the west wing, though I did wander a bit, perhaps getting lost in the extensive hallways.

record.question: Ms. Thompson, were you aware of any recent disagreements or conflicts Jonathan Blackwood was having with anyone?
record.feedback: : I overheard Jonathan mention a frustrating negotiation with a potential buyer for the bronze statue a few days prior, but I didn't catch any names.

record.question: Mr. Sinclair, were you the potential buyer Ms. Thompson overheard Jonathan Blackwood discussing regarding the bronze statue?
record.feedback: No, I was exclusively interested in a painting from Mr. Blackwood’s collection and had no discussions regarding the bronze statue.

record.question: Ms. Harcourt, can you elaborate on the nature of the criticism Mr. Blackwood leveled against your work? Was it public, or did it occur in private?
record.feedback: It was very public, unfortunately, and significantly damaged my reputation within the art community.

record.question: Mr. Grey, you mentioned a view of the gardens from your hotel room. Did you observe anyone else in the gardens during the evening?
record.feedback: Gardens? Oh dear, are we still talking about gardens? I, uh, I think I saw a squirrel, a very plump one, actually, and my aunt Mildred once kept pigeons, but that's entirely irrelevant, isn't it? No, I didn't really *look* at anyone else in the gardens, I was too focused on… on the light.

record.question: Ms. Bennett, you mentioned wandering the hallways. Did you happen to see anyone near the room where the bronze statue was displayed?
