record.feedback: Now that you mention it, I *think* I recall seeing a shadowy figure near that room, but it was quite dark and I couldn't make out who it was – perhaps someone admiring the statue as well?

record.question: Ms. Thompson, can you describe the bronze statue? Was it particularly valuable or unique in any way?
record.feedback: : It was an antique depicting a Roman emperor, and Jonathan mentioned it was a rare casting with significant historical importance, making it quite valuable.

record.question: Dr. Chang, can you describe the nature of your relationship with Dr. Fitzwilliam, and were there any recent disagreements or tensions between the two of you?
record.feedback: Our relationship was professionally complex, marked by disagreements regarding our joint research project that had become increasingly tense recently.

record.question: Ms. Grant, were you aware of Dr. Fitzwilliam’s controversial theories, and if so, did you ever discuss them with her or anyone else at the library last night?
record.feedback: I was vaguely aware of some academic debate surrounding Dr. Fitzwilliam’s work, but my discussions yesterday were solely focused on the logistics and planning of the upcoming exhibition, and I didn’t hear her discuss them with anyone.

record.question: Mr. Bennett, as head librarian, you would have been familiar with the library's layout and the location of all the artifacts. Can you confirm if the sphinx bookend used in the murder was usually kept in its place, and if you noticed anything unusual about its placement or the surrounding area yesterday evening?
record.feedback: Oh dear, the sphinx bookend… it’s just awful, truly awful, and you know my Aunt Mildred collected porcelain cats, a whole room full, and they were *very* delicate, unlike a sphinx, which is stone, and… well, yes, it was usually there, but I was mostly focused on the budget reports, they were quite alarming, really.

record.question: Mr. Clarke, you were at the library to interview Dr. Fitzwilliam. What was the subject of your interview, and did Dr. Fitzwilliam express any fears or concerns to you during your conversation?
record.feedback: I was researching the historical applications of rare botanical poisons for a novel I'm writing, and Dr. Fitzwilliam mentioned briefly being unsettled by some anonymous letters he'd received recently.

record.question: Professor Hartley, can you describe your professional relationship with Dr. Fitzwilliam? Were you aware of any professional rivalries or conflicts she was involved in, beyond what has already been mentioned?
record.feedback: Dr. Fitzwilliam and I had differing academic viewpoints, specifically regarding my research which she openly challenged, creating a tense professional atmosphere.

record.question: Dr. Chang, you mentioned tensions regarding your joint research project. Can you elaborate on the nature of these disagreements? What specifically were you and Dr. Fitzwilliam arguing about?
record.feedback: We fundamentally disagreed on the interpretation of the research data and the direction the project should take, specifically regarding the methodology used in the fieldwork.

record.question: Ms. Grant, you mentioned discussing the upcoming exhibition. Was Dr. Fitzwilliam involved in curating or lending any items to this exhibition, and if so, what were they?
record.feedback: Dr. Fitzwilliam was not directly involved in curating the exhibition, but she had expressed interest in lending a few rare maps from her personal collection, though we hadn’t finalized the details yet.

record.question: Mr. Bennett, can you recall seeing any of the suspects – Dr. Chang, Ms. Grant, Mr. Clarke, or Professor Hartley – near Dr. Fitzwilliam shortly before the estimated time of death?
record.feedback: Oh, goodness, people were coming and going all day, it was terribly busy, and I do get flustered easily, especially when the Dewey Decimal System is involved, and I believe I saw someone with a tweed jacket, but honestly, everyone wears tweed at the library, it's practically a uniform!

record.question: Mr. Clarke, you mentioned Dr. Fitzwilliam received anonymous letters. Did she mention anything about the content of these letters, or who she suspected might be sending them?
record.feedback:
, 

She didn't detail the contents, but she did say they alluded to her research and hinted at someone disapproving of her work with those very plants – it struck me as rather dramatic, honestly, and she seemed to think it was a disgruntled former student.

record.question: Can you describe your professional relationship with Dr. Blackwood, and had it become strained recently?
record.feedback: My relationship with Dr. Blackwood was purely professional, as I was researching him for a potential article and I hadn’t noticed any recent strain or unusual behavior.

record.question: When you were restoring the antique marble bust, did you notice anything unusual about it – any existing damage, or anything that might have made it easier to wield as a weapon?
record.feedback: Oh, goodness, the bust...it was just so *dusty*, you wouldn’t believe the layers, and I always worry about static cling with these old pieces, it’s terribly distracting, but no, I didn’t notice anything like…that.

record.question: Dr. Blackwood’s recent theories were controversial. Did you agree with his work, and if not, did you express your disagreements to him directly, perhaps leading to an argument?
record.feedback: I strongly disagreed with Dr. Blackwood’s theories, as they fundamentally challenged established archaeological principles, and I certainly voiced my concerns to him during the gathering and later in a private discussion.

record.question: You are a frequent donor to Blackwood University and collaborated with Dr. Blackwood. Can you describe the nature of your collaborations, and were there any recent disagreements regarding funding or project direction?
record.feedback: My collaborations with Dr. Blackwood primarily involved funding research initiatives at Blackwood University, but we recently disagreed about redirecting funds from a project honoring my late wife.

record.question: You were appraising artifacts at the manor. Can you detail exactly which artifacts you examined, and specifically, how long you spent examining the antique marble bust before the incident?
record.feedback: I was primarily focused on the collection of porcelain dolls and briefly looked at a silver tea set, and I honestly barely glanced at the marble bust, perhaps only a minute or two as it didn’t seem particularly valuable.

record.question: You mentioned researching Dr. Blackwood. Did your research uncover anything about his personal life – any debts, enemies, or hidden conflicts – that might shed light on a potential motive for murder?
record.feedback: My research focused solely on his academic work and the controversy surrounding his theories, and I didn’t delve into his personal finances or private relationships, but I did observe tension with Professor Harper.

record.question: Ms. Winters mentioned observing tension between you and Dr. Blackwood. Can you elaborate on the nature of this tension, and specifically, what was discussed during your private conversation?
record.feedback: The tension stemmed from our differing views on his upcoming publication, and during our private conversation, I expressed my professional concerns about its potential to mislead the archaeological community.

record.question: You mentioned disagreeing with Dr. Blackwood about redirecting funds from a project honoring your late wife. How significant was this disagreement, and did it escalate into a heated argument?
record.feedback: It was a very significant disagreement, and it did escalate into a heated argument in the library around 3:30 PM.

record.question: Besides dust, did you notice anything else unusual about the library that evening – anything out of place, or anyone behaving strangely?
record.feedback: The library…oh, it smelled strongly of beeswax polish, I always bring my own, but it might have been someone else's, and my Aunt Mildred once collected porcelain dolls, terribly creepy things, did you know that? No, nothing else… I think.

record.question: Can you describe the nature of your rivalry with Jonathan Blackwood, and when was the last time you spoke to him?
record.feedback: Oh dear, rivalry...well, my aunt Mildred always said I had a terrible sense of direction, and it’s just awful trying to remember things clearly, but the last time I spoke to Jonathan was, I believe, right there in the study, just before...before everything happened, and it was quite tense, you see, very tense indeed.

record.question: Can you describe your routine duties in the manor house, and specifically, where you were and what you were doing between 7pm and 9pm last night?
record.feedback: My routine duties involve maintaining the cleanliness and order of the manor, and between 7pm and 9pm last night, I was checking on the study, overhearing the argument, discovering the body, and alerting the staff.

record.question: What were the "controversial circumstances" surrounding your dismissal from Jonathan Blackwood's employment? Be specific.
record.feedback: My dismissal was simply a restructuring of staff following a change in company direction, and unfortunately, my position was deemed redundant.

record.question: You mentioned being at a family gathering. Can you detail who else was present, and specifically, what you were doing between 8:00 PM and 8:30 PM last night?
record.feedback: Honestly, I was mostly chatting with my aunt Carol and uncle David, and I believe I was getting another slice of pie around 8:15 PM, but it’s all a bit of a blur – was something *happen* around then that I should be concerned about?

record.question: Despite being estranged from Jonathan, did you have any financial ties to him, or were you aware of any recent changes to his will?
record.feedback: Naturally, as we were undergoing a divorce, my financial future was deeply intertwined with the settlement, and I was certainly aware of the existing will.

record.question: You said your conversation with Jonathan was "tense." Can you elaborate on the subject of that argument and what specifically was said?
record.feedback: Tense...oh, my goodness, it was tense, like a tightly wound clock, and actually, my shoes were a bit tight too, I really should have broken them in before this trip, but we were discussing the merger, naturally, and he kept mentioning something about due diligence and I said, well, I *think* I said something about confidence in my financial projections...or perhaps it was the weather? It’s all a blur, truly.

record.question: You seemed hesitant when asked about what happened around 8:15 PM. Is there a reason you’re being vague about that specific timeframe?
record.feedback: It’s just odd you’d focus on that exact time – does that timeframe have some significance to what occurred, and is it near where the… incident took place?

record.question: You mentioned overhearing an argument. Can you recall any specific words or phrases used during the argument between Jonathan Blackwood and Henry Caldwell?
record.feedback: I overheard a heated argument between Jonathan and Eleanor, not Henry, and unfortunately, I couldn't make out specific words, only raised voices indicating a tense disagreement.

record.question: You stated you were arguing with Jonathan. What was the argument *about* specifically, and did it involve any threats or displays of strong emotion from either of you?
record.feedback: The argument centered around the unfair division of assets and custody of our children, and while voices were raised, I wouldn’t characterize it as involving explicit threats.

record.question: Can you describe your professional relationship with Dr. Carter, and were there any recent disagreements or tensions between the two of you?
record.feedback: Dr. Carter and I had a wonderfully collaborative relationship, and we were excitedly planning a potential exhibition together featuring her recent discoveries.

record.question: Dr. Bennett, how did you react to Dr. Carter’s recent publication and the controversial theories she presented within it?
record.feedback: Oh, goodness, the book… it had a lovely cover, a really lovely shade of blue, and honestly, I was just so worried about finding the right shoes to wear to the event, you know how it is!

record.question: Can you describe your activities in the library on the evening of the murder, specifically between 7 PM and 9 PM?
record.feedback: rimarily, I was researching local folklore for a story I'm writing, and I believe I saw a man resembling the victim near the history section around 8 PM, which struck me as odd since it wasn't a typical area for that kind of research.

record.question: Professor Langley, were you aware of Dr. Carter’s research challenging established historical narratives, and if so, what was your opinion of it?
record.feedback: "Yes, I was aware of Dr. Carter’s research, and while I respected her dedication, I found her conclusions to be rather speculative and potentially damaging to long-held academic beliefs."

record.question: Mr. Reed, did you ever appraise any artifacts for Dr. Carter, and if so, can you describe the circumstances?
record.feedback: Yes, I have appraised artifacts for Dr. Carter previously, typically discussing potential acquisitions that would complement her research on historical pieces.

record.question: Ms. Collins, you mentioned planning an exhibition with Dr. Carter. Could you detail the specifics of this exhibition – what artifacts were to be included, and what role were you and Dr. Carter each expected to play?
record.feedback: We were envisioning an exhibition centered around Dr. Carter’s latest archaeological finds, specifically focusing on the historical context and artistic merit of the artifacts, with me curating the display and handling the gallery aspects while she provided the scholarly expertise.

record.question: You seemed to deflect when asked about Dr. Carter’s book. Can you be more specific about your concerns regarding her theories, and did those concerns ever lead to a direct confrontation with her?
record.feedback: Confrontation? Oh dear, no, absolutely not! I always make sure to have a peppermint before speaking publicly, it helps with my nerves, and the theories… well, they just seemed a bit… different, and I really shouldn't say more, it's all just so upsetting!

record.question: You mentioned seeing a man resembling the victim near the history section. Can you recall any details about this man – his clothing, demeanor, or anything he was carrying?
record.feedback: He was wearing a dark coat, seemed quite agitated, and I distinctly remember he was clutching a rather ornate, antique-looking letter opener, which now that I think about it, is a peculiar thing to have in a library.

record.question: Professor Langley, are you familiar with the antique bronze statue used as the murder weapon? Have you ever seen it before, and if so, where?
record.feedback: "Yes, I am quite familiar with the statue; Dr. Carter and I actually examined it together during a research project on historical artifacts several years ago at the Old Manor Library."

record.question: Can you describe your professional relationship with Dr. Carter, and were there any recent disagreements or tensions between you two?
record.feedback: Dr. Carter and I were colleagues who shared a mutual respect for each other's work, though we had differing opinions on the proper interpretation of recent discoveries, which led to some spirited debate.

record.question: What specifically were you hoping to uncover with your feature story on Dr. Carter, and had she expressed any concerns about your investigation?
record.feedback: I was hoping to highlight Dr. Carter's groundbreaking work with her recent Egyptian excavation and the significance of the artifact she discovered, and she didn't express any concerns about my journalistic investigation at all.

record.question: Can you describe your movements within the mansion on the evening of the murder, specifically detailing where you were between 7pm and 9pm?
record.feedback:
‌

Honestly, I was mostly wandering around, admiring the artwork and trying to find the library – I got quite lost, actually, and believe I was near the west wing around 8pm.

record.question: Were you aware of the artifact Dr. Carter recovered in Egypt, and if so, what was your professional opinion of its significance?
record.feedback: Yes, I was aware of the artifact, and as a museum curator, I believed it to be a remarkably significant find with the potential to reshape our understanding of that era.

record.question: Have you ever examined any artifacts recovered by Dr. Carter, and if so, under what circumstances?
record.feedback: Oh, goodness, artifacts...yes, well, I always make sure to pack an extra toothbrush when traveling, you never know, and this one...Dr. Carter's artifact, it was today, a consultation, a very important one, and it was quite fragile, really quite fragile.

record.question: You mentioned differing interpretations of Dr. Carter’s discoveries. Can you be specific about what those disagreements were, and did they involve the artifact brought back from Egypt?
record.feedback: Our disagreements centered on the artifact’s cultural origins – I believed it pointed to a previously unknown civilization, while she insisted it was a variation of existing dynasties, and yes, this applied directly to the Egyptian artifact.

record.question: Did Dr. Carter share with you any information about potential rivals or individuals who might have wanted to steal or discredit her work?
record.feedback: Dr. Carter mentioned a few academics who disagreed with her interpretations of the artifact, but she didn't suggest anyone would resort to violence or theft.

record.question: You stated you were near the west wing around 8pm. Can you recall seeing anyone else in that area at that time?
record.feedback:
‌

Now that you mention it, I *think* I briefly saw a shadowy figure disappearing around the corner near what I later learned was Mr. Hawthorne’s study – it was too dark to be certain, though.

record.question: If the artifact were to be stolen, what would be its value on the black market, and who would be the most likely buyers?
record.feedback: Determining an exact black market value is difficult, but considering its historical importance, it could fetch millions, and likely attract the attention of private collectors with questionable ethics or even national groups seeking to bolster their own cultural narratives.

record.question: Can you describe your relationship with Dr. Harper, and specifically, what you discussed the last time you spoke with her?
record.feedback: Dr. Harper was my mentor and a great inspiration, and we last discussed showcasing her newly discovered Egyptian artifact in an exhibit at the museum.

record.question: Were you aware of Dr. Harper's recent discovery in Egypt, and if so, what was your reaction to it?
record.feedback: Yes, I was aware of Dr. Harper’s discovery, and while monumental, I also felt it downplayed the importance of my own research.

record.question: Did you ever appraise any artifacts for Dr. Harper, and if so, can you detail those instances and the items involved?
record.feedback: Oh dear, oh dear...yes, I...I did appraise something for Dr. Harper today, a beautiful statuette, Egyptian, you see, and my grandmother always collected thimbles, quite a collection really, all silver...it was just today, and it was...remarkable, truly.

record.question: You mentioned seeing some people near the cabin. Can you recall specifically *who* you saw, and what time you saw them, providing as much detail as possible?
record.feedback: Mark Olsen and his wife, Beatrice, were walking near the cabin around 3 PM, and they seemed quite agitated about something, though I couldn’t make out what.

record.question: Were you working on any articles specifically about Dr. Harper or her recent discovery prior to her death, and if so, what was the focus of that reporting?
record.feedback: Yes, I was working on a feature article detailing Dr. Harper’s recent expedition in Egypt and the groundbreaking discoveries she made there, hoping to secure an exclusive interview with her.

record.question: Did you know about Professor Bennett's feelings regarding Dr. Harper's success, and did you ever discuss this with Dr. Harper?

You mentioned appraising a statuette for Dr. Harper today. Can you describe the statuette in detail – its size, material, any distinguishing features – and when exactly did Dr. Harper contact you about it?
record.feedback: It was...oh, it was quite old, I think, and shiny, a little bit...and my aunt Mildred always said I was terrible with dates, absolutely dreadful, but she called this week, I believe, yes, a week ago perhaps, and it was…golden, or maybe bronze, a little figure, and very important-looking, truly frightening to think about now.

record.question: Can you account for your whereabouts between 6 PM and 10 PM last night? Be specific.
record.feedback: I remained in my hotel room during those hours, attempting to process the difficult conversation I had with Dr. Harper earlier in the day.

record.question: You mentioned seeing Mark and Beatrice Olsen. Did you notice anything else unusual near the cabin that evening, anything at all, regardless of how insignificant it might seem?
record.feedback: Now that I think about it, I did see a gardening trowel lying near the rose bushes—it seemed odd since no one was gardening, and I believe Mr. Abernathy prized those roses immensely.

record.question: Mr. Collins, can you describe your relationship with Dr. Montgomery?
record.feedback: Oh dear, Dr. Montgomery... a lovely woman, truly, though I do prefer a good Earl Grey tea with a splash of milk, not black like she took it, and we were simply discussing a manuscript, a very old one, you see, quite fragile.

record.question: Professor Whitaker, were you aware of Dr. Montgomery’s recent fellowship award, and if so, what was your reaction to it?
record.feedback: >Yes, I was aware of Dr. Montgomery’s fellowship, and while I congratulated her publicly, I couldn’t help but feel a pang of disappointment considering my own years of dedicated research in a similar field.

record.question: Mr. Reed, did you happen to notice any unusual interactions or arguments between Dr. Montgomery and any of the other guests during the evening?
record.feedback: ‌Okay, well, now that you mention it, I *did* overhear a rather heated discussion near the library, but I couldn't quite make out who was involved, only that someone seemed quite upset with the Doctor about a… financial matter, perhaps?

record.question: Lady St. Clair, are you familiar with Dr. Montgomery's financial situation, and were you aware of any debts or disputes she may have had?
record.feedback: I was not privy to the details of Dr. Montgomery's personal finances, but I sensed a subtle tension with Professor Whitaker regarding a research matter.

record.question: Ms. Hastings, as an art curator, would you have been familiar with the antique brass candlestick used in the murder? If so, can you describe its history or provenance?
record.feedback: As a curator, I am generally familiar with antique candlesticks, but I didn't pay specific attention to that particular one and wouldn't be able to speak to its history.

record.question: Mr. Collins, you mentioned discussing a manuscript with Dr. Montgomery. Could you elaborate on the subject of this manuscript and why it was so fragile?
record.feedback: Fragile! Oh, terribly fragile, like my grandmother's china, which reminds me she collected thimbles, hundreds of them, and the manuscript… it was about… garden gnomes, no, wait, it was a first edition poetry collection, and it was fragile because of the age, naturally, and the paper was so thin!

record.question: Professor Whitaker, Lady St. Clair mentioned tension between you and Dr. Montgomery regarding research. Can you be more specific about the nature of this disagreement?
record.feedback: >We had differing interpretations of historical evidence, and a rather spirited debate about proper attribution—it's common in academic circles, though perhaps a bit more pointed in this instance.

record.question: Mr. Reed, you overheard a discussion about a financial matter. Can you recall anything more specific about the voices or the content of the conversation, even if it was just a word or phrase?
record.feedback:
‌ 

It was muffled, truly, but I believe I distinctly heard the name "Blackwood" mentioned with a tone suggesting a debt owed – a rather large one, if I'm not mistaken, and it struck me as odd because I thought Dr. Montgomery was a very careful man with his finances.

record.question: Lady St. Clair, are you familiar with anyone named Blackwood who may have had a financial relationship with Dr. Montgomery?
record.feedback: "I do not recall hearing Dr. Montgomery mention anyone named Blackwood, though she did discuss funding for her research with various patrons and organizations."
